DOC.HEAD: Islamic Demonstration in Algeria
Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with hundreds of thousands demonstrating, details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of thousands of Islamic fundamentalists, many of them women, gathered Thursday near the National Assembly to demonstrate for ``the dignity of Islamic women.'' The rally was intended as a reply to a recent spontaneous demonstration of women at the site to protest Islamic extremism and demand the strict application of Algeria's Constitution calling for equality of the sexes. Many of those at the peaceful gathering were women, with their heads covered by traditional Islamic scarves. Islam is the official religion of this North African country. About 10,000 demonstrators who rallied earlier were joined by hundreds of thousands of others, strictly separated according to gender. They blocked streets leading to the government building. Police looked on but no violence was reported. Loudspeakers broadcast verses from the Koran, the Moslem holy book. Banners praised Islamic law as the only moral guide and declared that women should be honored to wear the hijab, the traditional scarf covering head, neck and ears. It was the largest demonstration by women in Algeria since the country gained independence from France in 1962. The National Assembly, meanwhile, adopted a ban on political demonstrations at sites reserved for religious purposes. The fundamentalists, who control most of the 8,000 Algerian mosques, have increasingly used their sermons to denounce the ``westernization'' of Algerian society and the decline of strict Islamic values.
